item.title: Asymmetric Encryption
item.description: What Is Asymmetric Encryption? # Asymmetric encryption, also known as public-key encryption, is a method of encrypting data that involves two separate keys: a public key and a private key. These keys are mathematically linked but not identical, hence the term “asymmetric.” This method provides a secure way of encrypting and decrypting information, and it’s widely used in various forms of digital communication and security protocols How Does It Work?

item.title: TLS Handshake
item.description: TLS/SSL and HTTPS # TLS (Transport Layer Security) and its predecessor, SSL (Secure Sockets Layer), are integral to HTTPS, which stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure. HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, the primary protocol used for transmitting web pages over the internet. This post will introduce the process of TLS handshake, and the TLS version is TLS 1.2 TLS Handshake # Client to Server: ClientHello The client starts the handshake by sending a ClientHello message.

item.title: Session vs Token
item.description: Introduction # Both sessions and tokens are used for user authentication and maintaining user state across multiple HTTP requests in a web application. Process # Session-Based Authentication Process # 1-2: User Login Attempt The user submits their login credentials (usually username and password) through the client (e.g., a web browser). 3-4: Credentials Verification The server receives the credentials and verifies them against its user database or authentication source. 5-6: Session Creation
